newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany agrees on funding for Eurofighter -sources.
newsitem.headline: Germany agrees on funding for Eurofighter -sources.

text.p: The German government has agreed to spend more than two billion marks ($1.1 billion) in 1998 and 1999 to finance the four-nation Eurofighter military jet, Bonn coalition sources said on Tuesday.
Sources from Chancellor Helmut Kohl's centre-right government told Reuters the government would spend 850 million marks for the project in 1998 and 1.2 billion marks in 1999.

The decision assures that Germany will hold up its end of the project and order 180 Eurofighter planes as planned, news that project partners Britain, Italy and Spain have been anxiously awaiting.
The Eurofighter aircraft is scheduled to replace ageing Phantom jets from the year 2002.

The Bonn sources said that the agreement on the level of defence spending for 1998 and 1999 reached in budget talks between Finance Minister Theo Waigel and Defence Minister Volker Ruehe assured the project's funding for four years.
According to the agreement on defence spending, Ruehe will have a budget of some 46.8 billion marks ($26.7 billion) next year, nearly unchanged from the 1997 defence budget of 46.3 billion.
